author: protolambda
content:
Recently I have been looking into SSZ caching, tree-based representation of state, and construction of multi proofs, and think signing-root is problematic.
This, along with more related signing-root issues motivates me to propose to remove signing-root.
Full details here: https://github.com/ethereum/eth2.0-specs/issues/1487
Only a proposal, as it is related to frozen code. However, with the outlined benefits I am convinced it is worth the discussion.
Please take a quick look, I would like to discuss this during the implementers call tomorrow.

author: djrtwo
content:
> Is anyone aware of any documentation around eth2 sync algorithms?

There is currently only block sync. The calls in the networking spec enable the retrieval of blocks to do such a sync. I'm not certain if there is a description of the methods other than that document. I can ask on the call tomorrow.

Beyond that, we do need to specify a state sync, but it does not have to be available at the initial releaseof the protocol as validators are expected to serve historic blocks for the weak subjectivity period (at least 3+ months worth). Worth opening that up soon though if anyone wants to take a stab at it.

author: jgm
content:
Latest spec says "# Attestations must be for a known block. If block is unknown, delay consideration until the block is found"

Should nodes store these attestations or discard them (or only store them if they originated from one of their own validators)? Similarly, should they rebroadcast them periodically?

Seems like there are various strategies that could work, but only if all nodes do the same thing.

author: m.kalinin
content:
> Should nodes store these attestations or discard them

It should store them until this block comes from the wire. A node received an attestation to unknown block could request this block from a sender.

Attestation should be propagated only when it passed verification which is not possible unless node has a block.

author: jgm
content: Is that a potential DOS attack, where a node is flooded with attestations dfor invalid blocks?

author: m.kalinin
content: Sorry for late response. Yes, it is. The mitigation is to blacklist nodes that can't send you that block on demand. If node propagated an attestation to you it must get it verified which is impossible without having a block (this block must also be imported into this node's chain).

author: arnetheduck
content: we think of it as having two separate areas for attestations: one with unverified stuff and one with verified-and-working.. it's on the edge to the latter that we retransmit. the same goes for blocks - there's an in-memory pool for unverified blocks for which there are trimming heurestics.. once they're in the verified area, they're considered for consensus etc, before that they practically don't exist (for requests, consensus, database storage etc), except as records to be completed. there's a bit of an open question whether we should have a third, verified-lite pool specifically for propagation - if some verifications end up being costly, the verification latency will affect the network as a whole, and it could make sense to use partial verification

author: m.kalinin
content: It would be much easier if we have an ability to verify signature without state computations. Then verified-lite pool could run only signature verification. With the same fashion as ethash in Eth1. It seems that the only solution here is to include public key along with signature which is of 48 bytes cost; it would make attestation self-sufficient then. This is a trade-off between bandwidth and computation cost of attestation dissemination.
